text: Hi everyone. I am a long time vet of social media and copywriting and have a successful freelance career as well. Looking for some advice or feedback on how to charge for a project. Most of my freelance is per hour or project but I’m now going to be doing social media strategy for my friends band, which is fairly successful. There are no gigs to promote obviously but they have a new album coming out and need to promote the songs, digital stream/downloads, etc. my thought is more around a monthly retainer type of fee but not sure how to charge for something like as it will be ongoing and sometimes more frequent than not. Looking for some ideas around structured billing and how you’d charge more than what $$ you’d charge.

text:
I like the retainer approach, but with extra work = extra fees communicated clearly.

Possible approach: scope out what you feel would be the monthly minimum requirements in hours. If it's a generous amount of hours, consider discounting your hourly to reflect the bulk and ongoing deal.

Define what ala carte activities are in scope: e.g. regular and timely correspondence, fortnightly status checks, any kind of reporting, up to x hours of 1:1s, etc.

Then for out of scope, give some examples (e.g. graphic design needs, more than 3 revisions to copy) + the hourly on that. In your status meetings (these should happen no matter what, even if the meeting is an email), you should report on forecasted scope—are we going over? Are we waaaay under and you feel like you need more work, etc.

Get all this into a contract and get signatures. This part is the key!
